Number.Base.Converter

Class Base

  • java.lang.Object
    • Number.Base.Converter.Base

  • public class Base
extends java.lang.Object
    A base is nothing but symbols that, when combined in a certain order, represent values. With this class, it is possible to represent any base of as long as its symbols are supported by the primitive char.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static Base BINARY
      This is the binary base, which has only the symbols 0 and 1.
      static Base DECIMAL
      This is the decimal base, the most used base.
      static Base HEXADECIMAL
      This is the hexadecimal base, it has the digits 0 to 9 and the letters A to F.
      static Base OCTAL
      This is an octal base, it has the symbols 0 to 7.

    • Constructor Summary

      Creates a base with the symbols provided.

    • Field Detail

      • BINARY

        public static final Base BINARY
        This is the binary base, which has only the symbols 0 and 1.

      • OCTAL

        public static final Base OCTAL
        This is an octal base, it has the symbols 0 to 7.

      • DECIMAL

        public static final Base DECIMAL
        This is the decimal base, the most used base. It has the symbols 0 through 9.

      • HEXADECIMAL

        public static final Base HEXADECIMAL
        This is the hexadecimal base, it has the digits 0 to 9 and the letters A to F.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Base

        public Base(char[] symbols)
        Creates a base with the symbols provided.
        Some requirements:
        • There can be no repeated symbols;
        • It is not possible to use the symbols present in minusSign and floatingPoint.;
        • There must be at least two symbols;
        By default, minusSign is '-' and floatingPoint is '.'
        Parameters:
        symbols - the symbols to represent the numbers of that base

    • Method Detail

      • correspondingValueInDecimal

        public int correspondingValueInDecimal(char symbol)
        Returns the corresponding value of this symbol in base 10.
        Warning: if this symbol is not recognized it will throw a SymbolNotFoundException.
        Parameters:
        symbol - The symbol to get the value
        Returns:
        the corresponding value of this symbol in base 10

      • correspondingValueInThisBase

        public char correspondingValueInThisBase(int digit)
        Returns the value corresponding to this base symbol. Warning: if the value is less than zero, or greater than the base, it will throw a DigitOutOfBaseException.
        Parameters:
        digit - The digit to get the value
        Returns:
        the corresponding value of this digit in this base

      • getNumberBase

        public int getNumberBase()
        Returns the number of that base, that is, the number of symbols in that base return symbols.length;
        Returns:
        the number of symbols in that base

      • getSymbolAt

        public char getSymbolAt(int position)
        Returns the symbol at the given position. return symbols[position];
        Parameters:
        position - the position of the symbol
        Returns:
        the symbol at the given position

      • contains

        public boolean contains(char symbol)
        Returns true, if the informed symbol belongs to this base, and otherwise, false.
        Parameters:
        symbol - the symbol to be verified
        Returns:
        true if it belongs to the base, and otherwise, it returns false
